description: Erection of three storey house to the side of 1 Caverleigh with associated parking to the rear
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction method statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(j) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.The demolition and construction of the development shall be carried out in accordance with the construction method statement so agreed.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase, and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

A sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works on site above damp proof course level. The development shall  then be built in accordance with these approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methodshas been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordance with the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the dwelling and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays. Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The boundary treatment as shown on drawing number 1724/20 Rev C shall be completed prior to the first occupation of the development hereby approved unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority. Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

No development or other operations shall take place except in complete accordance with the approved drawing number TPP-01 Rev A and 'BS5837 Arboricultural Method Statement dated 5th November (by  Arbor Cultural Ltd) both received by the local planning authority on 6th November 2019  (hereinafter referred to as the Approved Scheme).a) No operations shall commence on site in connection with the development hereby approved until the tree protection works required by the Approved Scheme are in place on site. b) No excavations for services, storage of materials or machinery, parking of vehicles, deposit or excavation of soil or rubble, lighting of fires or disposal of liquids shall take place within an area designated as being fenced off or otherwise protected in the Approved Scheme. c)The fencing or other works which are part of the Approved Scheme shall not be moved or removed, temporarily or otherwise, until all works including external works have been completed and all equipment, machinery and surplus materials removed from the site, unless the prior approval in writing of the local planning authority has first been sought and obtained.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012 and to prevent unnecessary harm occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The first floor bathroom window fitted in the front (south) elevation shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. The windows shall be non-opening unless the parts of the windows which can be opened are more than 1.7 metres above the finished floor level of the room in which the window is installed and shall be permanently so-retained. Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the rear wall of the building hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The vehicle parking space shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the first occupation of development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times. Reason: To ensure adequate on-site parking provision in the interests of highway safety, convenience and amenity, in accordance with CS 7 (Managing Vehicle Use) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The secure cycle parking facilities shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The bin storage facilities shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential unit hereby approved shall not be occupied until it has achieved an energy efficiency standard of a minimum of 19% CO2 improvement over Building Regulations requirements Part L 2013 (TER Baseline).Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential unit hereby approved shall not be occupied until it has achieved as a minimum, a water efficiency standard of not more than 110 litres per person per day maximum water consumption (to include a fixed factor of water for outdoor use of 5 litres per person per day for in accordance with the optional requirement defined within Approved Document G of the Building Regulations).Reason: In the interests of Sustainability and Energy Conservation in accordance with Policies 5.2 (Minimising Carbon Dioxide Emissions) and 5.3 (Sustainable Design & Construction) of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 (Sustainable Design and Construction Standards) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The residential unit hereby approved shall not be occupied until the development has been built in accordance with the requirements of Category 2 of  the Building Regulations document titled 'Approved Document M - Access to and use of buildings'.   Reason: To ensure that the development provides a range of homes to meet different needs and to ensure compliance with Policies 3.5 and 3.8 of the London Plan (2016).

The flat roofs to the rear of the dwellings hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted  (2012).Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, the dummy entrance door and 25mm recessed rendered panels as shown on approved drawing number 1724/21 Rev A must be installed in accordance with the  facing materials samples that shall be approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works on site above damp proof course level.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to occupation of the development hereby permitted,  a landscaping scheme including where applicable the retention of the existing trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The applicant is advised that Condition 23 (Written Scheme of Investigation for an Archaeological Evaluation) of planing permission 20/02235/FUL will not be fully discharged until all works on site are complete and all the requirements of a Stage 2 Written Scheme of Investigation are satisfied.

The applicant is advised that the start date of the development in relation to planing permission  20/02235/FUL should be communicated by the archaeological practice acting on their behalf to Historic England and The Greater London Archaeological Advisory Service (GLAAS) in order that monitoring visits can be arranged as appropriate.
Condition 3 (Details of Materials) -  Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.
Condition 7 (Site Contamination) - The RBK Pollution Control Officer has reviewed the information submitted and is satisfied this can now be approved.

Condition 11 (Piling or Penetrative Foundations) - Thames Water have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.Thames Water advise the applicant that:Demolition, piling and excavation works all have the potential to adversely impact Thames Water assets. Please bearin mind that Thames Water will hold the developer and any relevant contractor/sub-contractor liable for any lossesincurred or damage caused to Thames Water assets arising from construction works or subsequent use of the facility. Condition 14 (Landscaping Scheme) - The RBK Tree & Landscape Officer has reviewed the information provided and is satisfied this can now be approved.
Condition 15 (Waste and Recycling Facilities) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.
Condition 16 (Secure Cycle Parking) - The RBK Sustainable Travel Officer has reviewed the information provided and is satisfied this can now be approved.
Condition 18 (Car Park Management Plan) - The RBK Pollution Control Officer and RBK Highways Engineer have reviewed the information provided and are now satisfied this can be approved.
Condition 21 (Construction Management Plan) - The RBK Pollution Control Officer and RBK Highways Engineer have reviewed the information provided and are now satisfied this can be approved.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan, Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

In accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

You have been granted planning permission to build a residential extension. When undertaking demolition and/or building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays. Furthermore, please ensure that all vehicles associated with the construction of the development hereby approved are properly washed and cleaned to prevent the passage of mud and dirt onto the adjoining highway. You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation. For further information and advice, please contact - Environmental Health Department Pollution Section.

Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021;- The South London Waste Plan 2012; - The LDF Core Strategy 2012; and,- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008.Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalThe application seeks the erection of a two storey side extension, single storey rear extension, and roof extensions, together with alterations to the fenestration and internal layout.Consultations6 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.Lead Local Flood Authority - Requests further information relating to surface water drainage.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; and- Flood risk and drainage.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed side extension would conflict with the guidance in the Council's Residential Design SPD, insofar as it would appear as a fully integrated extension. However, the adjoining semi-detached property, No. 42 Cambridge Avenue, already benefits from a fully integrated two storey side extension (see application reference 15/14579/HOU) and the proposed development would therefore restore a sense of balance to the pair. A sufficient gap (of approximately 1m) would be maintained between the side extension and the boundary of the site, and the characteristic two storey projection to the front elevation would be preserved. The proposed single storey rear extension would be of an unusual but high quality design, with appropriate detailing and finishes. The proposed roof extensions and alterations would amount to fairly typical domestic development. The box form of the dormer would not match the existing pitched main roof but officers recognise that it would sit comfortably alongside the existing box dormer at the adjoining semi-detached property (see application reference 15/14287/LDP).In any event, the proposed works to the rear of the property would not be readily visible from any public vantage points and would therefore have a limited impact on the character and appearance of the area.The alterations to the fenestration throughout the building would integrate well with the existing, being in a crittal style.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have a positive impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers are satisfied that the scale and siting of the proposed extensions is such that they would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light. The proposed side facing roof lights may give rise to unacceptable views over No. 46 Cambridge Avenue, but this could be effectively mitigated by a condition requiring obscure glazing. The remaining windows would offer similar views to those already available from the property.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Flood Risk and DrainagePolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.The site is located partly within Flood Zone 2. The applicant has submitted a site-specific flood risk assessment which sets out that floor levels within the extensions will be set no lower than existing in order to mitigate the risk of flooding to occupiers of the development. Officers consider this to be an appropriate measure but also recommend a condition requiring electrical sockets to be located at least 750mm above finished floor level.Notwithstanding the above, the applicant has not submitted any information regarding surface water management. Policy DM4 of the Core Strategy requires all proposals to include SuDS unless it can be demonstrated that this would not be feasible. The applicant has not demonstrated that inclusion of SuDS would not be feasible. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy DM4.ConclusionThe proposed development would have a positive impact on the character and appearance of the area, principally by restoring balance to the pair of semi-detached properties of which the application property forms part. This is a benefit that carries significant weight in favour of the proposal.The proposal is however contrary to policy DM4 of the Council's Core Strategy, which requires development proposals to include SuDS unless it can be demonstrated that this would not be feasible. However, officers consider that the scale of the proposed development would be such that it would not materially increase the risk of flooding, either to the site itself or elsewhere, as a result of surface water. Officers are also satisfied, subject to conditions, that the proposed development would not increase the risk of flooding from rivers. In light of these considerations, officers attach limited weight to the harm arising from the conflict with policy DM4.Officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable. This is a neutral matter.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal
Condition 3 (Front Boundary Wall) - Officers have reviewed the information provided and are satisfied this can now be approved.

Officer ReportIntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Section 38(6) of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004 states that planning applications must be determined in accordance with the development plan unless material considerations indicate otherwise.The development plan for the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames comprises the following documents:- The London Plan 2021- The South London Waste Plan 2012 - The LDF Core Strategy 2012- The Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling and detached garage.ProposalThe application seeks the erection of a two storey side extension and the erection of an outbuilding, following demolition of the existing garage. Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.Lead Local Flood Authority - Objection on the grounds of insufficient information relating to surface water drainage.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers; and- Flood risk and drainage.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed side extension would be large in scale and would not appear as a subordinate or proportionate addition to the dwelling. The ridge of its roof would not be set down at all from the ridge of the main roof and its front wall would not be set back from the main front wall of the dwelling at first floor level. It would therefore appear as a fully integrated extension and, given that it would significantly exceed half of the width of the existing dwelling (even before the return facing Raeburn Avenue is taken into account), it would appear to dominate its host. Its irregular footprint would also be a highly unusual feature for the area and the entirely blank nature of the elevation facing Raeburn Avenue would further add to its incongruous appearance. It is recognised that the existing extension to the adjoining semi-detached property, 1 Northcote Avenue, is also of a fully integrated design. However, permission for that extension was granted in 1989 and planning policy has changed significantly since. In particular, the Residential Design SPD 2013 sets out guidance for the design of two storey side extensions and the proposed development, for the reasons set out above, would conflict with much of that guidance.The proposed outbuilding would have a more typical appearance and, unlike the proposed side extension, would not be especially prominent within any public views. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development, by reason of the scale, siting and detailed design of the proposed side extension, would appear as an unduly prominent and incongruous feature within the Raeburn Avenue street scene, resulting in harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed side extension would conform to the front and rear elevations of 91 Raeburn Avenue. Given this, together with the fact that this property does not have any windows in its northern flank elevation, officers are satisfied that the proposed side extension would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light. The proposed fenestration would offer similar views to the existing i.e. towards the front and rear of the dwelling. The proposed extension would not therefore result in any materially harmful loss of privacy.Likewise officers are satisfied that the scale of the proposed outbuilding would be such that it would not appear overbearing or unduly deprive neighbouring occupiers of natural light.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Flood Risk and DrainagePolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF. Policy DM4 also requires developments to incorporate sustainable drainage systems unless it can be demonstrated that this would not be feasible.The application site lies partly within Flood Zone 2. The applicant has submitted a site-specific flood risk assessment but this does not consider sustainable drainage systems, nor does the application form provide any further information on this topic. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy DM4 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.ConclusionThe proposed development, by reason of the scale, siting and detailed design of the proposed side extension, would appear as an unduly prominent and incongruous feature within the Raeburn Avenue street scene, resulting in harm to the character and appearance of the area. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the Core Strategy 2012. Officers attach significant weight to this harm.The proposed development would not utilise a sustainable drainage system and the applicant has failed to demonstrate that this would not be feasible. The proposal is therefore contrary to policy DM4 of the Core Strategy 2012. However, given the scale of the proposed development, as well as the fact that the extensions and outbuildings would be located wholly within Flood Zone 1 (which is the area at the lowest risk of flooding), officers consider that it would not materially increase the risk of flooding to the site itself or elsewhere and that it would be unreasonable to resist the proposal on this basis. Officers therefore attach limited weight to the conflict with policy DM4.The principal benefits associated with the proposed development would be derived from the improvement to the living conditions of the occupiers of the property through providing increased living space. This is a very limited, private benefit.The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable. This is a neutral matter.Having regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be contrary to the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be granted, officers conclude that planning permission should be refused.Background PapersIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 The Plans / Drawings / Documents submitted with the application are available on the Council's website.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal

As part of the Agent for Change principle, this development has been provided with noise mitigation measures and supplementary ventilation. In the event of a complaint being made to the Council of noise from the nearby sports pitches, including the 5-a-side pitches, the Council will make a formal assessment with these noise mitigation measures in place. This will include windows being kept closed.

Your attention is drawn to the need to comply with the relevant provisions of the Building Regulations, the Building Acts and other related legislation. These cover such works as - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works. Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts. A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.

Please provide revised existing and proposed floor plans/elevations at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire floor plan, not just part and all key dimensions for the proposed works.Unfortunately the plans do not scale correctly at given scale of 1:50. Please amend and re submit.

Please provide a revised copy of block plan scaled 1:500 or 1:200 showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.
Please revise and resubmit a copy of an Ordnance Survey based site location plan scaled 1:1250.

Please provide a revised copy of block plan scaled 1:500 or 1:200 showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.

Could you please provide an email address for the applicant, as this is required at the decision notice stage.Could you also please advise of an address we could forward the laminated site notices to once the application has been validated, for them to be posted up on site.

Please provide a copy of proposed block plan scaled 1:500, providing a scale bar showing the proposed works (hatched or shaded) in relation to the existing dwelling, site boundaries and any outbuildings on site.  The block plan should also show adjoining properties to the side and rear and those opposite in full outline.The submitted proposed block plan does not have a scale bar.

Please provide proposed roof plans at a recognised scale of 1:50 or 1:100, providing a scale bar, showing the outline of entire property not just part and showing dimensions of proposed work.The submitted proposed roof plan has 4nos front rooflights, whereas the proposed front elevation does not show any rooflights, please amend the drawing accordingly.

Please complete the pre application form and return a copy to this office.The Council operates a Pre-application advice service, through which you will be able to obtain the advice of a Planning Officer. Please provide a payment of £3120 to accompany your application. This payment can be made online at www.kingston.gov.uk or by calling our Customer Care Line on 020 8547 5022

Please note that the quality of advice will be proportionate to the level of information provided, therefore it is to the applicants benefit to provide as much supporting information as possible for the proposal. eg: plans and elevations, photographs and supporting documents.

Could you please provide an email address for the applicant, as this is required at the decision notice stage.Could you also please advise of an address we could forward the laminated site notices to once the application has been validated, for them to be posted up on site.
